titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Alcyone Boat Club records 1977.065
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-04-02 19:13:01 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: This collection includes various records of the Alcyone Boat Club of Brooklyn, including the Club's constitution and bylaws, 1867; a log book recording miles rowed by members, 1878 to 1883; a history of the Club, circa 1875; and a membership list, 1859 to 1885. Also include is a court notice for the hearing of Otto Kornewann v. the Steamship PLANTYN, 1885.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Alcyone Boat Club was organized in Brooklyn 1854. Its first boathouse stood at the foot of Court Street in the neighborhood of Brooklyn Heights and was moved later to the neighborhood of Bay Ridge.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Alcyone Boat Club records, 1977.065, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection includes various records of the Alcyone Boat Club of Brooklyn, including the Club's constitution and bylaws, 1867; a log book recording miles rowed by members, 1878 to 1883; a history of the Club, circa 1875; and a membership list, 1859 to 1885. Also include is a court notice for the hearing of Otto Kornewann v. the Steamship PLANTYN, 1885.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
